author: Ross Lydall
title: Woman's life saved by same heart doctor for second time in 25 years | London Evening Standard
text:
Tuesday 28 February 2017 10:42 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard “Old friend”: Samantha Blake with Professor Shakeel Qureshi Nigel Howard 
A woman born with a heart defect has had a pioneering procedure carried out by the same cardiologist who helped to save her life when she was a baby. 
Samantha Blake, 27, is one of the first people in Britain to be fitted with a new type of heart valve which saves patients who have had open-heart surgery from a second major operation. 
The minimally invasive procedure — involving threading the valve into the heart via a vein in the groin — was performed at St Thomas’ Hospital by Professor Shakeel Qureshi, who was in the surgical team that operated on Ms Blake at Guy’s Hospital 25 years ago, when she was 17 months old. 
Ms Blake, a barrister’s clerk from Haywards Heath, West Sussex , said: “I felt in very safe hands with Professor Qureshi — he is like an old friend because he has looked after me since I was a newborn.” 
Ms Blake was born with Tetralogy of Fallot, which causes oxygen-rich and oxygen-depleted blood to mix, giving babies bluish-looking skin. It affects about one in 3,000 babies in Britain. Samantha as a young heart patient 
Tetralogy of Fallot patients usually need a second operation to repair their pulmonary valve when adults, but until recently replacement valves were too small for 80 per cent of people. 
Ms Blake believed that her heart was beginning to fail two years ago when she felt breathless after climbing stairs or walking up hills. 
“Leaving it wasn’t an option because it would have continued to deteriorate and eventually my heart wouldn’t have worked properly,” she said. 
“My breathing returned to normal immediately after the procedure. I feel lucky to be one of the first people to have the new replacement valve, it’s like a weight has been lifted knowing that the leakage has been stopped.” A new device — called the Venus valve — made from animal heart tissue, is being used in a clinical study at St Thomas’ Hospital and is available in much larger sizes. 
Professor Qureshi said: “Around 100 people have had the valve implanted in the world and the majority have had good results. This is a very exciting development.” More about:
